Award.AwardTitle: Evaluating Ethical Product Havens in the Global Economy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will examine the evolution of trade patterns in the ethical diamond market, focusing specifically on how they have evolved since the late 1990s when Canadian diamonds entered and quickly cornered the so-called "ethical" market. This project will focus on how consumers and retailers evaluate different ethical products, and how "ethical havens" - production sites favored for their ethical credentials, to the relative exclusion of others - are formed and challenged over time. This research will contribute to public policy debates about ethical market access and outcomes for countries and firms. In other words, how do countries or individual operations gain ethical consumers' and retailers' trust and allegiance? In light of the advocacy of ethical markets as means of economic development and social and environmental regulation by institutions such as the World Bank and the US Agency for International Development (USAID), it is important to provide communities, firms, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), national governments, and others with insights about how to actively intervene to increase the viability of those projects with the most benefits on the ground or, more fundamentally, whether or not to pursue ethical markets in the first place. The researcher will share the results of this research through summary reports, speaking engagements, and media outreach. She will also convene a workshop on ethical havens to foster comparative work (including a book project) on ethical markets and their spatial outcomes across multiple industries, and will mentor undergraduate and graduate research assistants in qualitative and quantitative data gathering and analysis.

One of the key questions surrounding so-called ethical markets is who benefits? While there is evidence of price premiums and other benefits for producers, there is also evidence of the dilution of ethical standards over time and the exclusion of the most progressive practices and smallest producers. In the case of ethical diamonds, the market has diversified over time, with new African empowerment discourses backing product offerings from a range of countries, and a diversity of retailer trajectories (i.e. some switching away from Canadian diamonds, others sticking with them, and yet others diversifying). The question remains, to what extent have the challenges to Canada's ethical monopoly actually changed the market? Specifically, how much market share have different ethical alternatives, including Canadian diamonds, gained and lost over time; how have their governance structures and marketing strategies changed over time; and, what factors explain these market shifts? This project will combine quantitative and qualitative analysis, including the creation of a database of ethical product offerings and representations (including changes over time), in-depth interviews with retailers and other stakeholders, and consumer surveys. Since consumer and corporate cultures vary geographically, this study will take a comparative approach, focusing on potential national and sub-national differences among major ethical diamond markets (the United States, Canada, and the UK).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research was driven by the question of whether ethical products, meaning products that are marketed and purchased at least partially for their social or ethical credentials (think fair trade coffee) are actually producing benefits for the communities most in need. The ethical diamond market is an interesting case study because it began specifically as a competition among countries of origin starting in the late 1990s, with Canadian officials and diamond producers trading on Canada's reputation to position Canada's new diamond mines as the ethical alternative to conflict diamonds from Africa (often represented in the singular despite the fact that diamond-fueled conflicts were limited to a small number of African countries). There were several responses to the conflict diamond issue, including the Kimberley Process Certification Scheme (KPCS), a UN-led initiative developed to stem the flow of conflict diamonds. While the Kimberley Process targets "rough diamonds used by rebel movements or their allies to finance wars against legitimate governments," it does not address many other social and environmental concerns. There has also been growing dissatisfaction with Canada's ethical monopoly, including concerns about negative environmental and Indigenous community impacts, and questions about why Canada (and not other diamond-producing countries) should benefit from the ethical diamond trade. In other words, there is significant debate about what constitutes an ethical diamond source, and this research traced the evolution of the market over the past 20+ years, as competition between places and product types developed.

It can be difficult to evaluate ethical product markets because of data limitations. In the case of the ethical diamond market, there is no trade data on the different types of diamonds sold as ethical. This research piloted a new methodology, using an online archive - the Wayback Machine, to evaluate shifts in countries' ethical market share. We found that what started as an exclusively Canadian market in the early 2000s has rapidly diversified. It's clear that the early ethical market was focused on avoiding Africa, with synthetic (aka lab-created), recycled and Russian origin stones added to the ethical diamond market. Over time, and largely as a result of the promotional work of the industry-backed Diamond Empowerment Fund (DEF), a range of African diamond sources, particularly those from large-scale, industrial producers such as South Africa, Botswana and Namibia, get incorporated into the ethical market. Interestingly, 2019 marked a clear turning point in the market, with synthetic diamonds overtaking Canadian (and all other) diamonds in terms of discursive market share (i.e. number of retailers offering each ethical diamond type). This does not mean that these were necessarily new diamond sources or represent new conditions of production. Rather, in many cases, this growth represents a rebranding of existing diamond sources.

The project also revealed that the evolution of the ethical diamond market is really a tale of three markets. There is a small, mission-oriented market of jewelry designers, small retailers, and ethical sourcing consultants that is still working toward a fair trade model.  The second sub-market consists of the major industrial mining companies and large retailers working on blockchain traceability initiatives to maintain their credibility. Finally, there is the rapidly growing synthetic diamond market with a large and growing number of producers and retailers that should be treated as a new manufacturing sector rather than a traditional extractive industry. There are also new sustainability and responsible mining standards in development for both the synthetic diamond and industrial mining sub-sectors.

One of the goals of this project was to inform advocacy and governance strategy, and breaking the market down into these sometimes overlapping but quite distinct sub-markets allows for the specification of unique governance possibilities and challenges. For instance, within the mission-oriented market there is potential for new linkages between jewelry designers/small retailers and artisanal producers, although there are significant barriers on the production side, as there are few already-organized cooperatives to link up to. And on the buyer side, there are few wholesalers or groups who can buy the full "run of mine". This reveals that efforts to change consumer or retailer values are not enough to actually make fair trade production a reality. Within the industrial diamond mining sector there is potential to push back against the country of origin framing of the blockchain traceability initiatives which obscure sub-national differences and limit the utility of the blockchain data for other governance actors such as NGOs and community representatives; there is also room to advocate for more redistribution of mineral royalties back to producer communities, and to support rights-based policymaking (focused on rights to land, to resources, to cultural preservation, to ecological functioning, and more). Finally, within the synthetic diamond space there is a need to reframe production as manufacturing and factory work rather than lab space in order to begin to address the social and environmental conditions of production.
